summary: A letter from the attorney for the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program to Judge Alison J. Nathan, requesting an extension to comply with a subpoena from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team. The letter explains the volume of materials (6,000-7,000 pages) and outlines a plan for partial production by the court's deadline and full production by the original subpoena return date.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the United States v. Maxwell case, to whom the letter requesting a document production extension is addressed.

persons.name: Patrick J. Smith
persons.role: Attorney for the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program
persons.context: The author of the letter, representing the administrator of the compensation program, outlining the plan for document production in response to Maxwell's subpoena.

events.title: Court Denies Motion to Quash Subpoena
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order denying a motion to quash Ghislaine Maxwell's subpoena to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program administrator and ordered document production by November 24, 2021.

events.title: Original Court-Ordered Production Deadline
events.description: The court's order required the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program administrator to produce subpoenaed documents by noon on this date.

events.title: Original Subpoena Return Date / Requested Extension Deadline
events.description: The original return date for Maxwell's subpoena was 8:30 AM on this date. The letter requests an extension to complete full document production by this time.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of New York, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
Smith Villazor LLP, 250 West 55th Street, 30th Floor, New York, NY 10019
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team subpoenaed the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program for documents.
The program's administrator, through attorney Patrick J. Smith, requested an extension to produce approximately 6,000 to 7,000 pages of potentially responsive materials.
The initial production plan included claim forms, narratives, payment records, and releases from four specific individuals identified in the subpoena.
The court had originally set a subpoena return date of November 29, 2021, but later ordered production by November 24, 2021, prompting the request for an extension back to the original date.
The document reveals the Maxwell defense was seeking information from the victims' compensation program, likely related to witness credibility or prior statements.
